headline: Chef John's Classic Guacamole
description: Chef John uses classic techniques to bring out more intense flavors in this classic avocado dip.

video.description: There's nothing quite as healthy and delicious as Chef John's classic guacamole.
video.name: Classic Guacamole

name: Chef John's Classic Guacamole
recipeIngredient: 0.5 teaspoon kosher salt for grinding vegetables, plus more to taste
1 lime, juiced, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Place minced peppers, 1/4 cup of the chopped cilantro, and the diced onions on a cutting board. Chop them together into very small pieces. Sprinkle with kosher salt. Using the flat side of the knife blade, smear the mixture to work it into a paste, and chop again to achieve as fine a texture as possible.

Stem, halve, and pit the avocados. Scoop out flesh and place in a bowl. Add 1/4 cup chopped cilantro, onion and serrano mixture, salt, and fresh lime juice. Mash with a potato masher to desired texture (smooth or chunky), 5 or 6 minutes. Taste and adjust seasonings. If not serving immediately, cover and refrigerate.

review.reviewBody: Just stumbled onto this recipe recently and have been looking forward to trying it. Well, the avocados finally ripened and I gave it a shot -Wow! This recipe does not disappoint! I like things spicy so I added an extra serrano but other than that I just followed along with Chef John's directions. As the Chef says, the mashing and dicing of the aromatics really brought out the flavors and made this Guac really pop! I will be making this again.

I would personally add 2-3 cloves of fresh garlic, especially so if you're leaving out the peppers. A sprinkle of msg and/or a couple drops of soy or "seasoning" sauce (as you'll find it labeled at many asian grocers) can really elevate the flavor. But for the basic recipe, really just the lack of garlic is my only issue.
Love this recipe over the others. I was able to use on toast and it was amazing. I never thought to use the lime twice. It really made a difference when it came to the oxidation of the avocados.
Very easy & great taste. The quantity of Cilantro & lime are have tried several recipies I
little to mushy, but good flavor

Delicious and simple! Mashing the onion and cilantro together is a game changer! I should have tasted before adding more salt at the end though, mine is just a bit salty, but will be great on chicken enchiladas.
I love guacamole and don't like when people add unnecessary things. This is simple but perfect.
I did make some changes like jalapeños instead of the suggested peppers and onion powder. But it was sublime!

We did a tasting of this guacamole and a Rick Bayless one. Although there were only minor differences in ingredients we all loved this recipe the best. I tried another guac recipe after our taste test to make sure, and this one was still our winner. The flavor is great, the texture great and the flavors do not get bland the next day either. This is my new go to guac recipe. I should have known too, I've loved everything I've ever made by Chef John!
I have never liked guacamole. This stuff is night and day better than anything I've ever had before. Made it by directions with no changes. I'll be keeping this stuff around to snack on.
I made this for a family dinner, everyone loved it. The only thing different I did was use a mortar and pestle for the chopped veggies. Best guacamole I have ever made.
I made it as written except I used a jalapeño. As I had a bunch from my garden. It is the best guacamole I have ever had. Yum. I will be making this for a party next weekend.
The grinding is key - I used a mortar and pestle! Came out awesome with almost no leftovers (there were only 4 of us:)
The grinding is key - I used a mortar and pestle! Came out awesome with almost no leftovers (there were only 4 of us:)

I forgot to get the peppers, so I used cayenne for heat -- my favorite, actually. Everything else I did according to the recipe, mushing and chopping and smushing. Best guacamole I ever made, and my husband agrees. I'm off to buy a molcajete and more avocados!

simply awesome, control your own heat,
get the guacamole saver from The Grommet and it stays beautifully fresh for a week or more

simply awesome, control your own heat,
get the guacamole saver from The Grommet and it stays beautifully fresh for a week or more
This is a great recipe. I loved it. Will make again.

Made exactly as written but omitted optional diced tomatoes. Did sneak in a smidgen of ground cayenne pepper but the guilt quickly faded after tasting this concoction. Makes an excellent guacamole that is bursting with flavor. Preferred this healthy version that doesn't use dairy products such as sour cream. First time, it's helpful to watch his video to master tips and techniques, and, as usual, get a few laughs. Another wining recipe by Chef John!!

Only used about 1/3 cup of tomatoes, otherwise followed the directions...

Easy, and as good as our favorite Mexican restaurant's version!
Best recipe so far. Tastes great and just the right balance of heat, tomato, and onion. Only used half a lime. Definitely a keeper.
Delicious and easy. You can make any consistency you like.
Delicious, everyone loved it. I used green onion instead of white onion and jalepeno pepper rather than serrano only because that is what I had on hand. This will be my go to guacamole from now on.
I've made this recipe several times. And I love it. Wouldnt change a thing.

Perfect! Thank you for the chop and smear technique
in the video. I used kosher salt and the texture of the final mix of cilantro, chili, and onion blended easily with the avocados and was delicioso! I had fresh jalapeños on hand; will be on the lookout for Serranos next time.

Thank you, Chef John, for the recipe and the training!
No changes. Used it on cheeseburgers .Great!
Excellent recipe

I've never made guacamole with serrano chilis before, but from now on I always will! I used this recipe as a base, but made some changes:
- Added 1 minced garlic clove
- Used red onion instead of white
- Used 2 chili peppers instead of 3
- Added 1/4 tsp ground cumin
- Omitted the cilantro (I have the cilantro-soap curse).

I've never seen guacamole go so quickly before. It's always a go-to party dip, but this, with the changes I made, was above and beyond.
Loved it, I am yet to make anything from Chef John that was a success or delicious!

Followed recipe with the exception of the Serrano chili which I substituted with a jalapeno. Served a large crowd watching a football game and everyone loved it. Will definitely make again and again....

I made this for a Cinco de Mayo party with friends. Everyone made something appropriate but this dish was the big winner. I followed the instructions exactly (I did not add tomatoes) and it was perfect. I have made guacamole often and always used more ingredients, but never again. This is clean and the flavors burst out. Chef John is the man.

Yes! Chef John makes Guac even better. Great technique but I used my mortal/pestle for that. I made double cilantro/onion/Serrano mash to freeze 1/2 for next go round. I did add a clove a garlic, 1/2 tsp of cumin and 1 smallish roasted jalapeno as I like those added flavors. Used the optional fresh tomato as well. Great stuff you can add more heat/spices for your liking. Ole'!
Very good! Great flavors. Watch the video to get the technique. Chef John is great!

As with everything "Chef John" I've made, this was great. 

 I added a couple tablespoons of chopped fresh mint.
Never disappointed and will put this with my go to recipes.
Wonderful recipe I can adjust the heat to my liking. Thanks
Like always ! Starting to wish I was married to this man ! He is awesome in the kitchen! Another crowd pleaser!
Family all really enjoyed this recipe.
Delicious! Made a half recipe. Used 1/2 roma tomato, seeded; seeded the serrano pepper, and added a pinch of garlic powder. Will use this "smashing" technique for the vegetables from now on.

As always, Chef John did not disappoint. I have made this recipe three times now for my foodie friends and they all keep raving about it. The secret really is in grinding the ingredients together until they release those juices that put this guac over the top, so make sure you take the extra effort to follow the technique as closely as possible. I suggest watching the video. I have made plenty of these recipes over the years (as I'm sure many of you have as well) but never have I achieved results like this.
Delicious! I love the technique of smashing the onions, cilantro and peppers with salt. It makes the final product much smoother.
I substituted the tomatoes for a can of Rotel, drained. Great recipe
